content:
What an amazing adventure you're planning! Capturing the Aurora Borealis is a thrilling experience, and the right gear can make all the difference. Besides the Manfrotto MHXPRO-3WG tripod head, here are some other essentials to consider bringing along:

1. **Tripod legs**: A sturdy tripod is crucial for capturing the Northern Lights. Look for legs that can withstand wind, snow, and cold temperatures. Consider carbon fiber or aluminum legs with a wide base and adjustable height.
2. **Camera body and lenses**: Bring a camera body with good low-light performance, such as your Nikon D750. A wide-angle lens (e.g., 10-22mm or 14-24mm) and a fast prime lens (e.g., 24mm or 35mm f/1.4) will help you capture the vastness and detail of the Aurora.
3. **Remote shutter release or camera timer**: A remote shutter release or camera timer will help minimize camera shake and ensure sharp images.
4. **Extra batteries and memory cards**: Bring spare batteries and memory cards to ensure you don't run out during the shoot. Cold temperatures can affect battery life, so it's better to be safe than sorry.
5. **Lens warmers or hand warmers**: Keep your lenses and hands warm with lens warmers or hand warmers. This will help prevent condensation and keep you comfortable during the shoot.
6. **Aurora forecast app**: Download an Aurora forecast app (e.g., Dark Sky or Aurora Service Europe) to track and predict the best viewing times and locations.
7. **Headlamp or flashlight**: A headlamp or flashlight will help you navigate in the dark and see your camera settings.
8. **Insulated camera bag**: Protect your gear from the cold with an insulated camera bag or case.
9. **Warm clothing and layers**: Dress warmly and bring layers to stay comfortable during the shoot. You may be standing still for extended periods, so it's essential to stay warm and dry.
10. **Snacks and hot beverages**: Bring snacks and hot beverages to keep your energy levels up during the shoot.
11. **First-aid kit**: A small first-aid kit can come in handy in case of minor accidents or injuries.
12. **Weather-resistant camera housing or cover**: Consider a weather-resistant camera housing or cover to protect your gear from snow, wind, and moisture.

For Iceland specifically:

1. **Waterproof gear**: Bring waterproof gear, such as a waterproof camera bag or housing, to protect your equipment from water and moisture.
2. **Microfiber cloth**: A microfiber cloth will help you clean your gear and remove water spots.
3. **Icelandic power adapter**: Don't forget to bring a power adapter for Iceland's Type F power sockets.

For Alaska:

1. **Bear spray**: If you plan to venture into bear country, bring bear spray as a safety precaution.
2. **Mosquito repellent**: Mosquitoes can be a nuisance in Alaska during the summer months, so bring some repellent to keep them at bay.

Remember to check the weather forecast before your trip and pack accordingly. It's also a good idea to research local regulations and guidelines for photography in the areas you plan to visit.

Have an amazing trip, and I hope you capture some breathtaking images of the Aurora Borealis!
